captions.text:
I relish a chance to go into a game knowing 
nothing about it. It&#39;s like how I prefer to
be paddled by someone wearing a mask so we don&#39;t have to make awkward conversation
about it later while waiting for the bus.

I didn&#39;t know anything 
about Scarlet Nexus but the title, which told

me jack shit, although it does sound like a bad 
erotic fiction author&#39;s euphemism for lady bits.
&quot;Her scarlet nexus quivered in anticipation as he unveiled his magenta ambassador.&quot;
There was also the one image on the
Steam page which seemed to depict some Jawas from Star Wars with orange tubes
coming off them like they&#39;d rigged up a Lucozade delivery system. Which was intriguing
enough, so I immediately started
it up in preparation for something wholesome and sports drink related,

only for everyone to pull their hoods down 
and go &quot;Psych! It&#39;s an anime game!&quot; D&#39;oh, you
got me again, anime. &quot;We sure did, fuckface! Now choose your protagonist.
Do you want to be tedious generic anime
schoolgirl who thinks the best way to convey seriousness of character is

to have the emotional range of a bathroom sink 
or tedious generic
anime schoolboy who remains

inexplicably oblivious to every female character 
in the game openly vying to knob him?&quot;

Oh well, at least if it&#39;s a Japanese game it&#39;s 
not just going to be another Jiminy Cockthroat
or survival crafter like everything that comes out of the west.
But then again, Japan has its own

Jiminy Cockthroats, or overrepresented tropes. 
Let&#39;s take a look at the story, for example.
Earth has been ravaged by apocalypse except for an outpost of humanity with access
to really advanced technology for some reason,
and this outpost is being constantly assaulted by mysterious monsters,

necessitating the creation of a 
defensive force of people with
superpowers or special technology,

almost none of whom for generally unexplored 
reasons are old enough to shave. Now, which

action sci-fi anime did I just describe? Basically 
all of them? Yes, that was my thought. It also

describes several Japanese games I&#39;ve played, 
including Astral Chain, Xenoblade Chronicles X,

that Attack on Titan thing, and there tend to 
be lot of similarities in the way gameplay&#39;s

structured. Generally there&#39;s a core combat 
mechanic with a hack and slashy emphasis and

lots of very elaborate finishing moves that 
involve jumping very high and going yah.

This combat is relegated only to fenced off 
arenas while the rest of the gameplay consists

of exploring open areas full of very interesting 
scenery mostly behind invisible walls while the

only things you can interact with are a hundred 
copy pasted NPCs that all have one dialog line
that plops out of their mouth whenever you press on their head like a fucking pez dispenser.

Oh, and the story will feature a cast of diverse 
characters with unique weapons and haircuts,
including enough waifus to cover all the standard archetypes,
if not a full on dating sim mechanic  because as we all know erotic fan art
accounts for something like 97% of the Japanese economy. If we might as well
think of everything I just listed as the Japanese equivalent of Jiminy Cockthroat,
Chihiro Cockthroat if you will, then this cock has been completely enveloped by the Scarlet
Nexus, and the result feels inescapably generic, but for the plot occasionaly going in slightly

bananas directions that make me think it was 
a mistake for the game to divide it across
two parallel campaigns. &#39;Cos whichever path you pick you&#39;re going to miss out on a few
bananas plot points that kinda lose something when just being verbally described to you at the

bits when generic anime boy and generic 
anime girl meet up to compare notes

&quot;Hi, we just got back from Narnia, where we 
learned that the monsters are actually made

of jam and all along one of our party members 
was secretly an artisanal jam maker from the

dark side of Mars.&quot; &quot;Well, I know you&#39;re too 
boring a character to have made up something

like that up.&quot; But let&#39;s stick our fingers up the 
primary gameplay loop and check it for prostate
cancer. The core combat is based around you being a psychokinetic
who can fling bits of scenery at  enemies,
and also has a big sword, but that goes without saying. First day of anime protagonist
high school you get the big sword with your campus map and your homework diary.
So comboing involves switching
between twatting with sword and twatting with random chairs and radiators and things,

and honestly I&#39;m not sure I like it. In the heat 
of battle you don&#39;t seem to have a lot of power
over which random bookshelves and wheelchairs your powers are going to fling at

the target, how long it&#39;ll take for them to get  
there or if they&#39;ll hit from the right angle to

smack into their dangling hairy weak spot. And 
it&#39;s let down by some dodgy control choices.

Like having to press two buttons to switch 
the targeter back to the main threat you&#39;re

trying to focus on because the game fucking 
autotargets anything you hit even if you&#39;re

only giving it a courtesy maiming in passing.
And while there&#39;s an interesting abstractness

to the monster design it&#39;s fucking hard to intuit 
what they&#39;re about to do.
Oh, that one&#39;s stomping its high heeled shoes

and wiggling the garden gate 
it has for a face. Is it about to charge or trying

to find a Wi-fi signal? I can&#39;t fucking tell. The 
other gimmick is your fellow party members
whose unique powers you can borrow to augment your attacks
or add other buffs and conditions,

but what with having to include every character 
archetype including Inexplicable Asshole Boy,
Dude Everyone Calls The Old Man &#39;Cos He&#39;s Over Twenty Five and
of course a full waifu inventory, there&#39;s kind of
too many party members to keep in mind. Especially when the two factions join

forces halfway and suddenly we have to deal 
with double tapping shoulder buttons to switch

between character wheels. Quick question, 
game: are you Microsoft Windows? No? Then

don&#39;t use double clicks for interface 
navigation in the middle of combat. And

don&#39;t use Microsoft Windows in combat, either, 
thinking about it. Speaking of party members,
the game plays up the relationship mechanics by having these little chillout sessions in
between  story missions where you increase your bond with the party by making conversation
and passing out whatever presents you crafted from the random bullshit you found in the last
mission&#39;s bins. And it&#39;s a right pace killer. Especially after, again, the two protagonists&#39;
factions join forces  and suddenly you&#39;re hosting a fucking office Christmas party and
have to mingle around listening to everyone&#39;s anime bullshit for half an hour because if you
don&#39;t you won&#39;t be able to make your sword
attacks strawberry flavoured in combat. After all that I can&#39;t think of much
that recommends Solar Plexus. I liked the monster visual design and some of the plot
curveballs were fun, but the combat
is full of little annoyances and there&#39;s a lot of the critical path gameplay that feels
obnoxiously padded out. It is also  simultaneously anime as dicks
and anime as balls. And I understand that
saying that will immediately turn off half the audience and electrify the other

half, but it often seems to be going out of its 
way to hit all the points on the anime checklist

and comes out feeling like a terribly generic 
anime action RPG. When anime waifu #3
appeared  and my anime schoolboy protagonist
introduced her as his &quot;childhood friend&quot; I remember literally

saying aloud &quot;Of course she fucking is. And 
oh look, she&#39;s secretly in love with someone.
Can I guess who? Is it 90&#39;s era David Duchovny?&quot;
&quot;Ooh, good guess, but think slightly blander.&quot;
